rows.user_query: Need an HP laptop for everyday use under $650. Prefer a 15.6-inch touchscreen with at least 16GB RAM.

Need a 2-in-1 or detachable tablet+keyboard laptop under $800 in the US with active stylus support and 7+ hours battery life. Prefer something under 16 inches, USB-C charging, and suitable for college notes, writing, browsing, and light gaming (e.g., Terraria at 1080p/60 on medium). Must work well with Linux (Debian/Mint), and refurb/used is preferred.

Looking for a premium thin-and-light ultrabook in the US up to $4000, prioritizing battery life, build quality, and portability (ideally <3 lbs and <0.7 in thick) with a 14"-class display (14.5" max). Needs an Intel CPU, 32GB RAM, at least 2x USB4 and 2x USB-A 3.2 Gen2, plus dual M.2 NVMe slots (prefer 2280). Primary workloads include compiling large codebases, running multiple Docker containers/VMs, and casual photo/video editing.
rows.agent_message: Which brand do you prefer for a premium 14-inch ultrabook?

rows.user_query: Need a $1000–$1500 laptop in the USA for a statistics PhD, mainly to run large Bayesian simulations in R. Priorities are performance, strong build quality, and good battery life; weight/size should be backpack-friendly and no touchscreen. Open to refurbished/used and wants it to last, with possible light-to-moderate gaming later (e.g., Baldur’s Gate 3).

Looking for a Windows laptop for a neuroscience/business student under $1200 with a ~14-inch matte, non-touchscreen display. Priorities are fast performance for heavy multitasking (Office + streaming + 20+ browser tabs), durability, light weight, and 8+ hours of battery life. Considering Lenovo ThinkPad X1 (2024) or Surface Laptop 7, but not a MacBook.
rows.agent_message: What’s your minimum RAM requirement for smooth multitasking (e.g., 8 GB, 16 GB, 32 GB, 64 GB)? Feel free to also share Storage Type

rows.user_query: Looking for a $400–$500 laptop (open to used/refurb) to stream from a PS5 using a capture card and add overlays plus a face cam. Performance is the top priority; weight, thinness, and screen size don’t matter. Also needs to handle video editing.

Need a portable ~14" laptop for an incoming biology major, with good battery life and a good keyboard. Prefer a touchscreen for digital note-taking (open to 2-in-1), and open to used/refurb options under $1000. Fingerprint reader and backlit keyboard/build quality are nice-to-haves.
rows.agent_message: What minimum RAM would you prefer for your laptop? Feel free to also share Brand

rows.user_query: Looking for a gaming laptop mainly to play Fortnite, The Sims 4 (with expansions/mods), GTA, and Stardew Valley. Wants to stay around $1,000 or less if possible, and is open to refurbished/used. Weight/thinness and extra features are not important.
rows.agent_message: What will you primarily use the laptop for? Feel free to also share Minimum RAM, Screen Size, Brand.

rows.user_query: Need a durable used/refurb 15-inch Windows 11 laptop for a garage/vehicle workshop budgeted at $230. It should handle basic office/web tasks plus vehicle tuning/diagnostic software, with ~3–4 hours battery life and the ability to connect to a TV. Prefer 16GB RAM, 256GB+ SSD, and a 1080p display; considering Lenovo ThinkPad models (P53s/T15/E15/L15).

Looking for a US laptop with good build quality and performance for online school, CAD work, and light gaming (e.g., Project Zomboid, Kenshi, Minecraft). Budget is $600–$1,000 but willing to pay more if the upgrade is significantly better. Refurb/used is fine; no strong preferences on weight or screen size.

Looking for a new 15"+ laptop ideally in the $400–$500 range (max $650) focused on performance. Main use is playing World of Warcraft Classic at max settings with 60+ FPS, plus basic web browsing and streaming. No refurb/used and no need for touchscreen; will use an external mouse.
rows.agent_message: Which brand would you prioritize for a 15-inch gaming laptop? Feel free to also share Storage Type.

rows.user_query: Looking for a gaming laptop in the US with a budget around $2000. Preferably a 16-inch screen. Will be used for MMOs and shooter games.
rows.agent_message: What minimum RAM do you require for your gaming laptop?

rows.user_query: Looking for a new work laptop under $1,000 USD with strong battery life (at least 6 hours) and high reliability. Prefer a 14–15 inch screen with the webcam at the top bezel, plus at least two USB ports and a headphone jack. Used mainly for Zoom and Microsoft Office; lightweight preferred but not required.
rows.agent_message: What minimum RAM would you consider for smooth Zoom and Office performance on a 14–15 inch business laptop? Feel free to also share Brand

rows.user_query: Looking for a reliable, well-built laptop for a 13-year-old in the US with a $600–$1,000 budget (willing to pay more if it’s a big upgrade). Needs good performance for online school, CAD work, and light gaming (e.g., Minecraft, Project Zomboid, Kenshi). Refurb/used is fine and there are no strong preferences on size, weight, or form factor.
rows.agent_message: What’s the minimum RAM you’d consider for a reliable school laptop that can handle online classes, CAD work, and light gaming, given a $600–$1000 budget and the option for refurb/used? Feel free to also share Screen Size, Brand

rows.user_query: Looking for a college laptop in the USA under $1400 (lower is better), open to refurb/used in like-new condition with original packaging. Needs good battery life and performance for SolidWorks, coding (VS Code/MySQL), and moderate gaming (Forza, Hytale, modded Minecraft), ideally in a 14–15" 2-in-1. Must have a touchscreen and OLED display; would like a good keyboard/touchpad and fingerprint reader.
rows.agent_message: What is the minimum RAM (in GB) you require for your college laptop? Feel free to also share Brand

rows.user_query: Looking for a good laptop from Costco in the US for up to $1000, new only (no refurbs/used) and not HP. Prefer a lightweight, thin laptop around 13 inches with all-day battery life, optional touchscreen, and reliable build quality. Needs to handle online classes and light gaming (Stardew Valley, indie games, visual novels); considering MacBook Air but concerned about game availability.
rows.agent_message: What minimum RAM do you want in your next laptop? Feel free to also share Brand

rows.user_query: Looking for a laptop in the US for $500 or less (refurb/used OK) that can run Foundry VTT at recommended settings for Lancer/DnD. Prefers a 16-inch or larger screen and would like somewhat rugged build if possible. Linux compatibility is preferred but not required.
rows.agent_message: What minimum RAM do you want to target for smooth Foundry VTT performance on a 16-inch+ laptop? Feel free to also share Brand.

rows.user_query: US aerospace engineering student with a ~$2000 budget wants a Windows 2-in-1 laptop with touchscreen/stylus note-taking to replace a MacBook Air/iPad setup. Needs enough performance for SolidWorks, MATLAB, and other engineering/CAD software, and should work well with a USB-C monitor/keyboard and Bluetooth mouse setup.

rows.user_query: Looking for a non-Apple laptop in the $700–$800 range for a college freshman. Needs to comfortably run Opera GX, Roblox, and Discord. Open to brands like Lenovo or Dell.
rows.agent_message: What’s the minimum RAM you’d be comfortable with for your new laptop? (e.g., 4 GB, 8 GB, 12 GB, 16 GB)

rows.user_query: Need a professional-looking 15–16" laptop for mechanical engineering school under $2000, with at least ~6 hours battery life and good performance. Must handle CAD/3D workloads (Fusion 360, SolidWorks, Blender) and programming (MATLAB/Python), plus some gaming (BeamNG, Forza, GTA). Open to open-box if it looks new and is portable for backpack carry.
rows.agent_message: What minimum RAM do you need for CAD/3D workloads (Fusion 360, SolidWorks, Blender) and multitasking on a 15–16" laptop? Feel free to also share Brand.

rows.user_query: Need a new Windows 2-in-1 laptop for college use, entertainment, light gaming (Roblox/Steam), and drawing with a touch screen and tablet/fold mode. Budget is $500–$700 USD (buying in the US), new only, with good battery life and portable enough for a backpack. Prefer a reasonably large screen plus good keyboard and touchpad.
rows.agent_message: What minimum RAM would you like in your new Windows 2-in-1 (for multitasking, drawing, and light gaming)? Feel free to also share Brand.

rows.user_query: Looking for a new MacBook under $3000 USD in the US, preferably around 16 inches. User is a software engineer prioritizing performance for running a Phoenix server and Claude Code, considering an M4 chip and unsure how to prioritize GPU vs memory. Prefers a model with a fingerprint scanner and is not open to refurb/used.
rows.agent_message: What is your minimum RAM requirement (in GB) for your MacBook?

rows.user_query: Recommend an up-to-date MacBook model suitable for professional applications. It should handle animation and game development workloads.

Looking for a new (refurb OK if like-new) laptop in the US for $1500, stretchable to $2000, prioritizing strong CPU performance and good battery life with reasonable portability. Needs 14–16" non-touch, non-OLED display ideally 1440p/60Hz, M.2 SSD with at least 512GB and upgradeable to 1TB+, and at least 16GB RAM (prefer 32GB if non-upgradable). Should handle light–moderate gaming (LoL, Slay the Spire, modded Minecraft at 1440p ~60fps) and programming/LaTeX, with USB-C DP Alt Mode and preferably a headphone jack.
rows.agent_message: Which laptop brands would you prefer for a 14–16" non-touch, non-OLED laptop with strong CPU performance, solid battery life, 16–32GB RAM, upgradeable SSD (512GB+), and 1440p/60Hz display? Feel free to also share Primary Use, Budget, and any other must-haves.

rows.user_query: Looking for a laptop in the $2000–$2500 budget range. Primary use is gaming, with some schoolwork.
rows.agent_message: What minimum RAM would you prefer for your gaming laptop? Feel free to also share Screen Size, Brand

rows.user_query: Looking for a lightweight 2-in-1 tablet-style Windows/Android device under $400 in the US (refurb/used OK) for on-the-go reading, writing, and photo/video editing. Must support touchscreen + pen and preferably have a removable keyboard, with better performance and higher RAM than a Surface Go to avoid lag when multitasking.
rows.agent_message: What screen size do you prefer for a lightweight 2-in-1 device under $400? Feel free to also share Brand.

rows.user_query: Looking for a basic, cheap laptop under $350 (USD) for web browsing, Microsoft Office, and reading PDFs. Performance and battery life are the top priorities, and lighter/smaller is preferred. Must have a backlit keyboard, a USB port for a flash drive, and a trackpad; open to refurbished/used if from a reputable seller and under warranty.

rows.user_query: Looking for a $1200 laptop in the US for a finance major that can handle Excel-heavy schoolwork and gaming (Minecraft, Roblox, Valorant) at medium–high settings around 60–120 FPS. Prioritizes performance first, then build quality and battery life, with moderate portability and a 14–16 inch screen. Needs a good keyboard, reliable build, at least 16GB RAM, and 512GB+ SSD; open to certified refurbished with warranty and wants it to last 4+ years.
rows.agent_message: Which brand do you prefer for your 14–16 inch gaming/finance laptop? Feel free to also share Brand.

rows.user_query: Looking for a used/refurb traditional 14–16" laptop in the US for under $1,000 with reliable build quality. Wants to game modern titles (indie to AAA) at medium settings around 60 FPS and also do music recording. Can reuse a 1TB drive and 32GB DDR5-4800 RAM from a prior laptop, so low storage/16GB configs are acceptable.

rows.user_query: Looking for a new lightweight 12–13" 2-in-1 with excellent pen support (palm rejection, color accuracy) for drawing and creative apps, plus enough performance to game. Budget is $2,000–$2,400 and battery life should support ~8 hours of productivity use. Wants to run Photoshop/CSP/Illustrator (possibly Blender) and play Warframe at high/max settings around 60+ FPS.

Need a portable college laptop (14in preferred, max 15in; under ~2.0kg) with strong performance and decent all-day battery life on a $1,200–$1,500 USD budget. Primary use is competitive FPS gaming on an external 1080p monitor (Apex/OW/Valorant) targeting ~200+ FPS, plus occasional light photo/video editing. Good keyboard is a must; open to used/refurb but cautious about scams.

Looking for a reliable, long-lasting laptop in the US with strong battery life for lectures and note-taking. Main use is multitasking for school/professional work: research with multiple tabs/windows, writing papers, creating presentations, and virtual meetings. Open to refurbished/used but prefers reliability; interested in repairable/upgradeable options like Framework.

rows.user_query: Need a reliable, long-battery-life laptop for an incoming US electrical engineering student, with enough performance for CAD and creative work (Blender, Onshape/SolidWorks, light video editing) plus some gaming. Prefers a portable 14-inch-ish laptop with good display for outdoor use, USB-C charging, and a microSD card slot, under $2000. Wants at least ~1TB fast storage and strong specs that will stay relevant for 4+ years.

rows.user_query: Need the cheapest possible laptop around $250 (can go a bit higher), open to used/refurb. rows.user_query: Looking for a Windows laptop in the US around $1,500 (new only) for Photoshop/Illustrator and light-to-moderate Steam gaming (cozy games, modded Minecraft). rows.user_query: Looking for a ~$1500 laptop (can go slightly over; refurb/used OK from reputable sellers) prioritized for performance for CAD (SolidWorks/Autodesk), slicers, and some 1080p gaming (~60 FPS). rows.user_query: Need a Windows laptop for music production with some casual gaming. Prioritize overall performance and reliability to stay useful for around 5 years. Requesting a couple of recommendations.

Need a well-built laptop with great battery life for a Mechanical Engineering BCS, budget $1500–$2000, open to used/refurb. It should handle potential SolidWorks use and Lightroom for photo editing. Considering MacBook vs Lenovo ThinkPad or similar alternatives, and should be comfortable to carry in a backpack.

Looking for a portable 11–13" Windows 2-in-1 that can replace an iPad Pro as a tablet-first device, with excellent battery life and strong performance for creative work.
